div.p: HIS MAJESTIES DECLARATION To all His loving SUBjECTS.
OF HIS TRVE INTENTIONS in advancing lately to BRAINCEFORD.
Printed by his MAIESTIES Command AT OXFORD, By LEONARD LICHFIELD, Printer to the Vniver≈øity, 1642.

div.head: HIS MAjESTIES DECLARATION To all his loving Subjects, of His true Intentions in advancing lately to BRINCEFORD.
div.p: THough Our Reputation be mo≈øt deare to Us, and e≈øpecially in tho≈øe ca≈øes, wherein the truth of Our mo≈øt ≈øolemne Profe≈ø≈øions (and by con≈øequence of Our Chri≈øtianitie) is que≈øtioned, yet it is not onely for the Vindicaton of that, and to cleare Our ≈øelfe from ≈øuch A≈øper≈øions, but withall to pre≈øerve Our Subjects in their ju≈øt E≈øteeme of, and Duty to Us, and from being engaged into Crimes and Dangers by tho≈øe malicious reports, ≈øo ≈øpightfully fram'd, and cunningly ≈øpread again≈øt Us, concerning Our late advancing to Brainceford, That Wee have re≈øolv'd to publi≈øh this Our following Declaration.

AT Colebrooke, on Friday the eleventh of November, We ‚Ä¢ received a Petition from both Our Hou≈øes of Parliament, by the Earle of Northumberland, the Earle of Pembroke and Montgomery, the Lord Wenman, Ma≈øter Perpoint, and Sir Iohn Hippi≈øly, And indeed We were well plea≈øed to ≈øee it ≈øo much liker to a Petition, then the other Papers Wee had often of late received under that name, and return'd to it the next day ≈øo gracious an An≈øwer, that Wee a≈ø≈øure Our ≈øelves could not but be very ≈øatisfactory to all that were truely lovers of Peace. The copies of both doe here follow.

div.head: To the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, The humble Petition of the Lords and Commons now a≈ø≈øembled in PARLIAMENT.
div.p: WE Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt loyall Subjects, the Lords and Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, being affected with a deep and pierceing ≈øence of the mi≈øeries of this Kingdome, and of the dangers to Your Maje≈øties Per≈øon, as the pre≈øent Affaires now ≈øtand, and much quickned therein with the ≈øad con≈øideration of the great effu≈øion of Blood at the late Battell, and of the lo≈ø≈øe of ≈øo many eminent per≈øons; And farther weighing the Addition of Lo≈ø≈øe, mi≈øerie and danger to Your Maje≈øtie and Your Kingdome, which mu≈øt en≈øue, if both Armies ≈øhould againe joyne in another Battell, as without Gods e≈øpeciall Ble≈øsing, and Your Maje≈øties concurrence with Your Hou≈øes of Parliament, will not probably be avoided.

We cannot but believe, that a ≈øutable Impre≈øsion of tenderne≈ø≈øe and Compa≈øsion is wrought in your Maje≈øties Royall Heart, being Your ≈øelfe an eye-witne≈ø≈øe of the bloody and ≈øorrowfull de≈øtruction of ≈øo many of your Subjects, And that Your Maje≈øtie doth apprehend what diminution of Your owne Power and Greatne≈ø≈øe will follow, and that all Your Kingdomes will thereby be ≈øo weakned, as to become ≈øubject to the Attempts of any ill-affected to this State. In all which re≈øpects, we a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelves that Your Maje≈øtie will bee inclined graciou≈øly to accept this our humble Petition, that the mi≈øery and de≈øolation of this Kingdome may be ≈øpeedily removed and prevented; for the effecting whereof we mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech Your Maje≈øty to appoint ≈øome convenient place, not farre from the City of London, where your Maje≈øty will be plea≈øed to re≈øide, untill Committees of both Hou≈øes of Parliament may attend your Maje≈øtie with ≈øome Propo≈øitions for the removeall of the≈øe bloody Di≈øtempers and Di≈øtractions, and ≈øetling the State of the Kingdome in ≈øuch a manner as may conduce to the Pre≈øervation of Gods true Religion, your Maje≈øties Honour, Safety and Pro≈øperity, and to the Peace, Comfort and Security of all your People.

body.head: His MAIESTIES An≈øwer to the afore≈øaid Petition.
body.p: WEe take God to witne≈ø≈øe how deepely Wee are affected with the mi≈øeries of this Kingdome, which heretofore Wee have ≈øtroven, as much as in Us lay, to prevent, It being ≈øufficiently knowne to all the World, That as Wee were not the fir≈øt that tooke up Armes, ≈øo Wee have ≈øhewed Our readine≈ø≈øe of Compo≈øing all things in a faire way by Our ≈øeverall offers of Treaty, and ≈øhall bee glad now at length to find any ≈øuch Inclinations in others, The ≈øame tenderne≈ø≈øe to avoyd the De≈øtruction of Our Subjects (whom Wee know to bee Our greate≈øt ≈øtrength) which would alwayes make Our greate≈øt Victories bitter to Us, ≈øhall make Us willingly hearken to ≈øuch Propo≈øitions whereby the≈øe bloudy di≈øtempers may bee ≈øtopped, and the great di≈øtractions of this Kingdome ≈øetled to Gods glory, Our Honour, and the welfare and flouri≈øhing of Our People; And, to that end, ≈øhall re≈øide at Our owne Ca≈øtle at Windfore (if the Forces there ≈øhall bee removed) till Committees may have time to attend Us with the ≈øame (which, to prevent the Inconveniences that will intervene, Wee wi≈øh may bee ha≈øtned) and ≈øhall bee ready there (or if that bee refu≈øed Vs) at any place where Wee ≈øhall bee, to receive ≈øuch Propo≈øitions as afore≈øaid from both our Hou≈øes of Parliament. Doe you your Duty; Wee will not bee wanting to Ours; God of his mercy give a Ble≈ø≈øing.

div.p: Being re≈øolved upon the≈øe Rea≈øons, That this advancing was nece≈ø≈øary and ju≈øt, Wee were not yet ≈øatisfied till Wee had endeavoured the ≈øame day (though the interruptions of ≈øhooting ≈øtopt up the way till the next) to ≈øatisfie Our Parliament and People of the ≈øame, and that Peace was ≈øtill Our de≈øire, Wee to that end directed a Me≈ø≈øage by Iohn White E≈øquire, which was ≈øo received, that his danger of being put to death, for bringing it, and impri≈øonment of him, and the Trumpetter that went with him, in the Gatehou≈øe, ≈øhew'd that the very Law of Nations was by ≈øome no more con≈øider'd then all other Lawes had beene before. A Copy of which Me≈ø≈øage hereafter followes, to ≈øhew how little temptation the matter of that gave them for ≈øuch an u≈øage.

body.head: His MAIESTIES Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. of November.
body.p:
WHereas the la≈øt night being the 11. of November, after the departure of the Committee of both Our Hou≈øes with Our gracious An≈øwer to their Petition, Wee received certaine Information (having till then heard nothing of it, either from the Hou≈øes Committer or otherwi≈øe) That the Lord of E≈ø≈øex had drawne his forces out of London towards Vs, which hath nece≈øsitated Our ≈øudden Re≈øolution
to march with Our forces to Brainceford; Wee have thought hereby fit to ≈øignifie to both Our Hou≈øes of Parliament, That Wee are no le≈ø≈øe de≈øirous of the Peace of the Kingdome, Then Wee expre≈øt in Our afore≈øaid An≈øwer; The Propo≈øitions for which Wee ≈øhall willingly receive where ever Wee are, And de≈øire (if it may bee) to receive them at Brainceford this night, or early to morrow morning; That all po≈øsible ≈øpeed may be made in ≈øo good a worke, and all inconveniences, otherwi≈øe likely to intervene, may bee avoyded.

div.p: ANd to ju≈øtifie yet further, that Our Intention was no other then was here profe≈øt, as ≈øoone as Wee were informed that the Earle of E≈ø≈øex his forces were departed from King≈øton, before any apparance or notice of further forces from London (Our end of not being inclo≈øed being obtained) Wee gave orders to quit Brainceford; and to march away, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe that place.

Wee cannot but make one Argument more of the truth of Our Profe≈ø≈øion, that this was all Our end, and that Wee had not the lea≈øt thought, by ≈øo advancing, to ≈øurpri≈øe and lack London (which the malignant party would infu≈øe into that Our Citty) And that is: That probably God Almighty would not have given ≈øuch a Ble≈ø≈øing to Our Iourney, as to have a≈ø≈øi≈øted Vs ≈øo both by Land and Water, as with le≈ø≈øe then a third part of Our foot, and with the lo≈ø≈øe but of tenne men, to beat two of their be≈øt Regiments out of both Braincefords, for all the great advantage of their workes in them, to kill him who commanded in chiefe, and kill and drowne many others, to take five hundred Pri≈øoners, more Armes, eleven Colours, and good ≈øtore of Ammunition, fifteene Peeces of Ordinance (whereof Wee ≈øunke mo≈øt that Wee brought not away) and then unfought with, and unoffered at, neerer then by Ordinance, to march away, notwith≈øtanding the great di≈øadvantage
of Our Forces by the difficulties of the Pa≈ø≈øages, if Hee who is the ≈øearcher of all hearts and truth it ≈øelfe had not knowne the truth of Our Profe≈ø≈øions, and the Innocence of Our Heart, And how farre Wee were from de≈øerving tho≈øe horrid Accu≈øations of fal≈øehood and Treachery ca≈øt ≈øo point blanke upon Our owne Per≈øon, That it would amaze any man to ≈øee them ≈øuffered to bee printed in Our Citty of London, if any thing of that kind could bee a wonder after ≈øo many of the ≈øame, and how really they de≈øire Accommodation, who upon this have Voted they will have none.

The≈øe Our Rea≈øons for this Action, this Our ≈øatisfaction ≈øent for it, and this Ble≈ø≈øing of God's upon it, (will We doubt not) cleere Vs to all indifferent per≈øons both of the Ie≈øuiticall Coun≈øels, and per≈øonall Treachery to which ≈øome have pre≈øumed ≈øo impudently to impute it; And God ≈øo ble≈ø≈øe Our future Actions as Wee have delivered the truth of this.
THE ANSWER OF BOTH HOVSES OF PARLIAMENT To his MAJESTIES Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. of November WITH HIS MAIESTIES Reply thereunto.
Printed, by His MAIESTIES Command, AT OXFORD, BY LEONARD LICH ‚Ä¢ IELD Printer to the Vniver≈øity. 1642.

div.head: The An≈øwer of both Hou≈øes of Parliament to his MAIESTIES Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. of November.
div.p: TO Your Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. of this Month of November, Wee the Lords and Commons in Parliament doe make this humble An≈øwer. That this Me≈ø≈øage was not delivered to us till Monday the 14. Wee thought it a ≈øtrange Introduction to Peace, that Your Maje≈øty ≈øhould ≈øend Your Army to beat us out of our Quarters at Brainceford, and then appoint that place to receive our Propo≈øitions, which, yet it plainely appeares, Your Maje≈øty intended not to receive till You had fir≈øt tried, whether you could breake through the Army rai≈øed for Defence of this Kingdome and Parliament, and take the Citty being unprovided and ≈øecure in expectation of a faire Treaty made to ≈øecure the Citty. If herein Your Maje≈øty had prevailed, after You had de≈øtroyed the Army and ma≈øtered the Citty, it is ea≈øie to imagine, what a mi≈øerable Peace Wee ≈øhould have had, and whether tho≈øe Cour≈øes bee ≈øutable to the Expre≈ø≈øions Your Maje≈øty is plea≈øed to make in Your An≈øwer to our Petition, of Your Earne≈øtne≈øse to avoyd any further Effu≈øion of bloud, let God and the World judge.

As for our Proceedings, they havein all things beene an≈øwerable to our Profe≈ø≈øions: wee gave directions to the Earle of E≈ø≈øex to draw the Army under his Command out of the
Citty and Suburbs, before wee ≈øent any Me≈ø≈øage to Your Maje≈øty. So that part of it was inquartered at Brainceford before the Committee returned with Your An≈øwer. And immediately upon the Receipt thereof, that very Morning Order was taken that the Souldiers ≈øhould Exerci≈øe no Act of ho≈øtility again≈øt any of Your Maje≈øties People. Wee ≈øent a letter by Sir Peter Killigrew to know Your Maje≈øties plea≈øure whether You intended the like forbearance of ho≈øtility. But the fury of Your Souldiers, thir≈øting after bloud and ≈øpoile, prevented the delivery of the letter. For comming upon Saturday in his way towards Your Maje≈øty as farre as Brainceford, hee found them in ≈øight there and could pa≈ø≈øe no further. God who ≈øees our Innocency, and that wee have no Aymes, but at his Glory and the publique good, will (wee hope) free Your Maje≈øty from tho≈øe de≈øtructive Coun≈øels who labour to maintaine their owne power by bloud and rapine, and ble≈ø≈øe our Endeavours, who ≈øeeke nothing, but to procure and e≈øtabli≈øh the Honour, Peace and Safety of Your Maje≈øty and Kingdomes, upon the ≈øure foundation of Religion and Ju≈øtice.

div.head: To the An≈øwer of both Hou≈øes of Parliament to His MAIESTIES Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. of November, His MAIESTIE makes this Reply.
div.p:
THat His Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. though not received by them till the 14. was ≈øent to them fir≈øt upon the ≈øame day upon which it was dated, and meeting with ≈øtops by the way, was againe ≈øent upon the 13. and taken upon that day at tenne in the morning by the Earle of E≈ø≈øex, and though
not to him directed, was by him opened, ≈øo the ≈ølowne≈ø≈øe of the Delivery is not ≈øo ≈øtrange as the ≈øtoppe of the Letter ≈øaid to bee ≈øent by Sir Peter Killigrew, which his Maje≈øty hath not yet received, but concludes from the matter expre≈ø≈øed to have beene contain'd in that Letter (to wit to know his Plea≈øure, whether Hee intended the forbearance of Ho≈øtility) and by the Command of ≈øuch forbearance ≈øaid to bee ≈øent to the Lord of E≈ø≈øex his Army, that no ≈øuch forbearance was already concluded, and con≈øequently neither had His Maje≈øty cau≈øe to ≈øuppo≈øe, that Hee ≈øhould take any of their forces unprovided and ≈øecure in expectation of a faire Treaty, neither could any Ho≈øtile Act of His Maje≈øties Forces have beene a cour≈øe un≈øutable to His expre≈ø≈øions, much le≈ø≈øe could an endeavour to prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe (for ≈øo Hee hoped Hee might have done) that Place, which might have ≈øtopt the farther March of tho≈øe Forces towards Him, (which, for ought appear'd to him, might as well have beene intended to Colebrooke as to Brainceford and by that the further effu≈øion of bloud, de≈øerve that ≈øtile.

His Maje≈øty farther conceives, that the Printing ≈øo out of time of ≈øuch a Declaration, as their Reply to his An≈øwer to their of the 26. of May, but the day before they Voted the Delivery of their Petition, and the March of the Earle of E≈ø≈øex his Forces to Brainceford ≈øo neere to his Maje≈øty, when the Committee at the ≈øame time attended Him with a Petition for a Treaty, the Earle of E≈ø≈øex being before po≈ø≈øe≈øt of all the other Avenues to his Army, by his Forces at Wind≈øore, Acton, and King≈øton, was a more ≈øtrange introduction to Peace, then for His Maje≈øty not to ≈øuffer Him≈øelfe to bee coopt up on all ≈øides, becau≈øe a Treaty had beene mention'd, which was ≈øo really and ≈øo much de≈øired by His Maje≈øty, that this Proceeding ≈øeemes to Him purpo≈øely by ≈øome intended to divert (which it could not doe) that His Inclination.

That His Maje≈øty had no intention to ma≈øter the Citty by
≈øo advancing, be≈øides His profe≈ø≈øion, which (how meanely ≈øoever they ≈øeeme to value it) Hee conceived a ≈øufficient Argument, (e≈øpecially being onely oppos'd by ≈øu≈øpicions and ≈øurmi≈øes) may appeare by His not Pur≈øuing His Victory at Brainceford, but giving orders to His Army to March away to King≈øton as ≈øoone as Hee heard that place was quitted, before any notice or Appearance of farther Forces from London; Nor could Hee find a better way to ≈øatisfie them before hand, that Hee had no ≈øuch intention, but that His de≈øire of Peace, and of Propo≈øitions that might conduce to it, ≈øtill continued, then by that Me≈ø≈øage of the 12. for which care of His Hee was required by ≈øuch a Reception of His Me≈ø≈øage and Me≈ø≈øeager, as was contrary at once both to duty, civility, and the very cu≈øtomes, and Law of Warre, and Nations, and ≈øuch as theirs (though after this Provocation) hath not found from Him.

His Maje≈øty wonders that His Souldiers ≈øhould be charged with thir≈øting after bloud, who tooke above five hundred Pri≈øoners in the very heat of the fight, His Maje≈øty having ≈øince di≈ømi≈ø≈øed all the Common Souldiers, and entertain'd ≈øuch as were willing to ≈øerve Him and required onely from the re≈øt an Oath not to ≈øerve again≈øt Him; And His Maje≈øty ≈øuppo≈øes ≈øuch mo≈øt apt and likely to maintaine their Power by bloud and rapine, who have onely got it by Oppre≈ø≈øion and Inju≈øtice; That His is ve≈øted in Him by the Law, and by that onely (if the de≈øtructive Coun≈øels of Others would not hinder ≈øuch a Peace, in which that might once againe bee the Univer≈øall Rule, and in which Religion and Iu≈øtice can onely flouri≈øh) He de≈øires to maintaine it. And if Peace were equally de≈øired by them, as it is by His Maje≈øty, Hee conceives it would have beene proper to have ≈øent Him ≈øuch a Paper as ≈øhould have contained ju≈øt Propo≈øitions of Peace, and not an unju≈øt Accu≈øation of His Coun≈øels, Proceedings and Per≈øon.
And His Maje≈øty intends to March to ≈øuch a Di≈øtance from His Citty of London, as may take away all Pretence of Apprehen≈øion from his Army, that might hinder them in all Security from yet preparing them to pre≈øent to him, and there will bee ready either to receive them, or to end the pre≈ø≈øures, and mi≈øeries, which His Subjects, to His great Greife, ≈øuffer through this Warre, by a Pre≈øent Battaile.
